Comment: This is the Najdorf variation of the Sicilian Defence. I play it as Black too.

I usually play this move. It is less aggressive than many other variations.
Black kicks the knight away and takes control of the d4-square. The downside is that the d5-square can be weak. Personally, I prefer e6, but that is just a matter of taste.
This move might appear overly cautious, but it is useful in many variations not to have the king on the g1-a7-diagonal, especially if the f-pawn moves.

This move is typical in Najdorf (and many other Sicilian variations). It gains space on the queenside, and the idea is often to play b4 attacking the c3-knight, which protects the e4-pawn. So Black is indirectly attacking the center!
With this move I am saying: "I am not afraid of b4!" Black cannot really win a pawn (see next move).
And Black goes for it.

This move is already utilizing the weak d5-square. Black cannot play 11...Nxe4 bacause 12. Bf3 f5 (or if the knight moves 13. Nxe7 Qxe7 14. Bxa8 or 12...Bf5 13. Qe1 with a similar idea if the knight moves) 13. Bxe4 fxe4 14. Nxe7 Qxe7 15. Qd5+ and Qxa8 wins a rook.
This move was a surprise to me. I expected Nxd5 or Bb7. Apparently, Black wanted to protect b4.
Winning the bishop pair and removing the defender of d6.
Developing a bishop and pinning the knight to the queen.
Developing a bishop and pinning the knight to the queen.
Threatens to take on e4.
Defending e4.
Now Black wants to push the bishop to a less favorable square.
Naturally, I want to keep the pin.
The pin is no longer there, but the pawn shelter in front of the king is weakened. One has to be careful with such moves.
I move the bishop to an open diagonal.
Natural development.
The bishop did nothing at e2. The drawback of Black's 11th move (a5) is now obvious. He doesn't control the b5-square anymore.
I don't understand this move. The a5-pawn is left without protection. Moving the other rook (17...Rfc8) would have been a good move.
